holdings.text: The jurisdiction conferred under s. 33A(2) of the Income-tax Act on the Commissioner is judicial/quasi-judicial; he has a duty to act judicially and the order is amenable to certiorari under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie the jurisdiction conferred under s. 33A(2) of the Act is a judicial one. The order that is brought before the Commissioner affects the right of the assessee. It is implicit in revisional jurisdiction that the revising authority shall give an opportunity to the parties affected to put forward their case in the manner prescribed. The nature of the jurisdiction and the rights decided carry with them necessarily the duty to act judicially in disposing of the revision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies three tests for quasi-judicial act (legal authority, affects rights, duty to act judicially) from precedents like Advani; textual analysis of s.33A(2) implies hearing and inquiry; distinguishes administrative acts.

holdings.text: Even assuming the Commissioner's order under s.33A was administrative, writ of mandamus lies against ITO to enforce s.29 duty.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, on the assumption that the order of the Commissioner under s. 33-A of the Act was an administrative one, the respondent would not be in a better position. What the appellant complains is that the Income-tax Officer in terms of s. 29 of the Act is under an obligation to issue a demand notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative holding: statutory duty under s.29 independent of Commissioner's order; Art.226 allows mandamus for public duty.

holdings.text: The affidavit in support of the writ petition complied with Allahabad High Court Rules Ch. XXII r.1(2); deponent's knowledge from records sufficient; not grounds for dismissal in limine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court mainly dismissed the writ petition on the ground that the affidavit filed in support of the writ petition was highly unsatisfactory and that on the basis of such an affidavit it was not possible to entertain the petition. [...] It is, therefore, not correct to say that the facts stated in the affidavit are not based on the deponents knowledge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of rules allows knowledge from perusal of records/documents; deponent specified sources; introductory facts immaterial.

holdings.text: If affidavit defective, High Court should have granted opportunity to rectify instead of dismissing in limine.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, if the affidavit was defective in any manner the High Court, instead of dismissing the petition in limine, should have given the appellant a reasonable opportunity to file a better affidavit complying with the provisions of r. 1 of Ch. XXII of the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural fairness; rules remedial, not technical dismissal.

holdings.text: Facts in affidavit complete and clear, not confused.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we agree with the High Court that the facts given in the affidavit are incomplete and confused. On the other hand, a careful perusal of the affidavit, along with the documents annexed thereto, discloses clearly the appellants case it gives the necessary facts and the reliefs sought for.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct reading of affidavit and annexures shows narrative coherent.

holdings.text: Revision lay to Commissioner under s.33A(2) against ITO's order as no appeal lay to AAC (no s.23(3) order or s.29 notice).
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33A proviso bars revision only if appeal maintainable but not filed/pending; here no s.23(3) assessment order, so no appeal under s.30.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer bound to issue notice of demand under s.29 when tax due consequent to Tribunal order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory language of s.29 ('shall serve'); tax due post-Tribunal directions.

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari issues quashing Commissioner's order; writ of mandamus directing ITO to pass order and issue s.29 notice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts.

edges.explanation: Holding h1 states that jurisdiction under s.33A(2) is judicial/quasi-judicial with duty to act judicially and amenable to certiorari, directly addressing whether the Commissioner's order was administrative and not amenable to writ

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie the jurisdiction conferred under s. 33A(2) of the Act is a judicial one. The order that is brought before the Commissioner affects the right of the assessee. It is implicit in revisional jurisdiction that the revising authority shall give an opportunity to the parties affected to put forward their case in the manner prescribed. The nature of the jurisdiction and the rights decided carry with them necessarily the duty to act judicially in disposing of the revision.

In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and we issue a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Commissioner and a writ of mandamus directing the Income- tax Officer to pass an order and issue a notice in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, if the affidavit was defective in any manner the High Court, instead of dismissing the petition in limine, should have given the appellant a reasonable opportunity to file a better affidavit complying with the provisions of r. 1 of Ch. XXII of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we agree with the High Court that the facts given in the affidavit are incomplete and confused. On the other hand, a careful perusal of the affidavit, along with the documents annexed thereto, discloses clearly the appellants case it gives the necessary facts and the reliefs sought for.

In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and we issue a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Commissioner and a writ of mandamus directing the Income- tax Officer to pass an order and issue a notice in accordance with law.
